newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: ZAMBIA SEES 30 PCT DROP IN 1997 MAIZE OUTPUT.
newsitem.headline: ZAMBIA SEES 30 PCT DROP IN 1997 MAIZE OUTPUT.

text.p: The Zambia National Farmers Union said on Friday that it expected the 1997 maize crop to fall by around 30 percent because of inadequate fertiliser stocks last year.
"We expect the maize harvest to fall by around 30 percent to 10.8 million 90kg bags," farmers union president Ajay Vashee told Reuters.
The maize yield in 1996 was around 14 million 90kg bags.
Fertiliser stocks into the country were delayed last year after South African suppliers witheld supplies until the Zambian government paid outstanding debts it owed them.
The government only managed to clear the arrears, totalling $10 million in October.
Vashee said the drop in maize production would mean that Zambia would suffer a shortfall of up to two million bags, but added that the stock level would depend on how much was exported.
Under new policies to liberalise the economy, farmers are free to export maize even when the country faces a shortage.
According to official figures, Zambia consumes around 12 million bags of maize a year. However, Vashee said the figure could be lower.
"A lot of people are switching to cheaper and drought-resistant crops such as sweet potato, cassava and sorghum," he said.
Vashee said the union expected fertiliser supplies to improve this year.
"There has been a co-ordinated effort between the private sector and the government to imrpove the fertiliser situation," he said.
Agriculture is becoming an increasingly important sector in Zambia as performance in the mining sector -- the hub of this dirt poor Southern African country's economy -- dwindles.
Agriculture contributed 28.7 percent to the 6.4 economic growth recorded in 1996, compared to 12.2 percent from mining.
